title-group.article-title: A New 3p14.2 Microdeletion in a Patient with Intellectual Disability and Language Impairment: Case Report and Review of the Literature

article-meta.aff: UOL of Medical Genetics, Department of Reproduction and Growth and Department of Medical Science, University Hospital S. Anna, Ferrara, Italy

author-notes.corresp: *Stefania Bigoni, MD, UOL of Medical Genetics, Department of Reproduction and Growth and, Department of Medical Science, University Hospital S. Anna, Via Fossato di Mortara 74, IT-44121 Ferrara (Italy), E-Mail bgs@unife.it

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright © 2018 by S. Karger AG, Basel

abstract.p: Interstitial deletions of chromosome 3p are rare, and specific genotype-phenotype correlations cannot always be assessed. We report the case of a 3p14.2 proximal microdeletion in a 60-year-old female patient with mild intellectual disability, severe speech delay, and mild dysmorphism. An array-CGH analysis detected a 500-kb deletion in the 3p14.2 region, including FEZF2, CADPS, and PTPRG. FEZF2 and CADPS are known to network within the neurodevelopmental pathways. It is possible that their rearrangements lead to the phenotypic features observed in the patient, and therefore, they can be considered candidate genes responsible for such abnormalities.
